content.description:
Interesting moves liven up this jug haul. 

  The name and FA are lost to time, the name "Three Star V2" comes from a hand-drawn topo from 1991.
content.location:
A short boulder down in the wash on the right-hand side of the trail as you enter the Harmonica Convention.  The South face (downhill side) of which has a hole that you sit-start in.  Walk off the uphill side. 

  Problem 1 in the picture.

content.description:
Another dangerous problem that is extremely pleasing to climb.  Not as clean as Colon Blow but a more interesting crux. 

  "You'd have to eat five million bowls of ordinary bran cereal to get the fiber equivalent of one bowl of Super Colon Blow." - Saturday Night Live 

  The line to the right, coming out the roof, is an open project.  Last worked by Jon Cardwell and Collin Horvat AFAIK.
content.protection: Luck or the ability to onsight solo 5.10.  Do not fall.
content.location: The middle line of the West face of Colon Blow boulder.  Stand start and pull through the overhang.  Some reachy moves.  Problem #8 in the picture.

content.description: Fingery, sustained, and powerful start lead to a spicy finish.  Good pad placement and spotting, however, can make this problem quite safe.  Lots of dynamic movement and body tension.
content.location: the far left, and shortest, line on the main face of Fight Club Boulder.  Sit start with left hand on a scoop and right in an undercling two-finger pocket, another two-finger pocket awaits the right after you pull off the ground.  Burl your way straight up and watch that landing zone!

content.description: Seems like everyone has different beta for this superb line.  Watch Ren & Stimpy for an explanation of the name.  Many other lesser lines on this boulder, see the guide for more info.
content.location: Down in the main clump of boulders, the trail goes right by this North-facing line.  Sit start and go up the blunt, overhanging arete using improbable-looking holds and smart feet.  Use the boulder to the Southeast to descend.  Problem 5 in the picture.

content.description:
A varied line combining slick slopers, small crimpers, funky footwork, roofy pulls and weird crosses. 

  Crux is gaining the crimpers.
content.protection: pads and spotters, pad that horrible sharp bush branch that will stab you.  Somebody stomped the bush for no reason and made this nasty skewer just for your back if you slime off the slopers.
content.location: Sit start in a big hueco on the South side of the East face of Colon Blow.  Immediately do moves up and left to gain two perfect crimps on the South face.  Dive left to jugs on the overhanging prow jutting out and clamber up over it to jugs to the right.  Problem #1 on the Dark Fighter picture.

content.description:
Nice explosive problem relatively low to the ground. 

  A tough start once you move off the hueco to a sloping hold out left. Figure out how to use this poor hold to move back to the right and a good edge without hitting the pads can be difficult. Once on the good edge out right, set your feet and fire for the square cut edge way above. This hold can be tough to hit in the right spot as you can only see the bottom of the block that you are going to the top of. Continue straight up with some more long reaches but on better holds.
content.protection: Pads and a spotter or two.
content.location: This in on the steep left hand side of the Fight Club Boulder as you are looking down into the gully from above. There are 3 main problems on this face, Project Mayhem is the furthest right, but not the arete. Start from a very low right facing hueco that is a bit bigger than a football.

content.description: Goofy little problem that is harder than it appears.  First done by Opie, who named it something really cool and then forgot the name.  Then done by Peck (not knowing about Opie's ascent) and named something equally as cool that no one can remember either.  Mysterious as the beta.
content.location: On the left-hand side and about 20 feet uphill from the main trail (to the Northeast).  West-facing, slightly overhung face with a big chalk-white starting jug that stands out like a pale porkchop.  Sit start on this chunk, go left using funky feet and then up the obvious line of holds.  Line 1 in the picture.
North-facing sit-start problem just Southeast of The Three Star V2.

content.description: A bit freaky at the start due to the big rock at the base.  But then gets juggy and the landing gets cleaner.  Crux is early on.
content.protection: pads and an attentive spotter.  A fall early on could be quite painful.  A bit highball to boot.
content.location: Just right of Super Colon Blow, just left of the roof project.  Sit start on a big pointy rock and go straight up thin holds to nice jugs at the top.

content.description: Sit start right of Dark Fighter with right hand in large shelf, and left hand on small crimp.  Pull up to large scoop using slopers and an optional knee bar.
content.location: Down climb the same way you got up.

content.description:
Combines power and precision.  Tensiony moves to get to a slopey, tenuous finish.  Would get more stars but is somewhat contrived. 

  First sent after a day of trying, long after the sun had set and to the faint glow of watch backlights.
content.location: On the overhanging, East face of Colon Blow boulder.  Sit start on smooth huecos and use underclings and sidepulls, including the obvious hand-sized vertical slot in the middle, to go straight up.  The large shelf to the right is off.  Problem #2 in the picture.

content.description:
This one will cut your left hand unless you tape it.  In fact, it is the only problem on Earth that Peck says requires tape. 

  I mention it here because the sit start from the big start hueco of Project Mayhem looks to add a lot of value to the problem.  It will also be somewhat hard, many "big names" have worked it, but it remains an open project. 

  UPDATE: The original FA, Jason Ploss, has sent from the sit start as of 2014/11/22 (and did not cut his left hand, though he poked a hole in a right finger working it a few weeks ago :-).  From the big hueco of Project Mayhem, the problem uses small holds and some nice foot jams and hooks in the hueco to go mostly left but a little up.  Then some very powerful pulling to free the feet to get set to throw.  I think you are out of luck if you want a grade, even a wild ass guess at this point, all I know is that it is significantly harder than fight club.  Anyway it looked pretty freakin' awesome.
content.location: Kindof in the middle of the East face of the Fight Club boulder, stand start on two terrible holds about at eye level.  Paste your feet, move the right hand in and slap the left horn, which is dismayingly bad and sharp to boot.  Problem #3 in the picture.

content.description: Approaching free solo height, this problem could maim or kill you.  But the rock is clean and solid, the moves long and juggy, and the committing cutting of both feet 15 feet up make this one of the most fun problems anywhere.
content.protection: Don't climb it!  Pads and spotters prolly can't help you due to the height and boulder landing.
content.location: On the overhanging West face of Colon Blow boulder, stand start the obvious left line of incut huecos.  Go up to the enormous feature jutting out over your head to the right, then top out straight up.  Line #7 in the picture.

content.description:
Tall and bad landing.  Crux puts you right over a jumble of rocks that are hard to pad.  However, I have seen many people fall there with no injuries, so proper spotting can help a lot. 

  A fun problem, it seems hard to walk by this and not do it.
content.protection: pads and a couple good spotters
content.location: On the right hand side of the East face of Fight Club boulder.  This line sit starts with a good crimp for the left and a baseball-sized hueco for the right.  Follow the jug line up and left along the arete.  Walk off the West side.  Line #5 on the Space Monkey picture.

content.description:
In a gully that gets a lot of sun, and well protected from the wind, with bouldering facing all directions for shade opportunities, this is usually a very pleasant place to boulder.  Good, well-established trails lead to the rocks. 

  Typical for Box, rock quality varies considerably.  Several dozen boulders yield several dozen problems of all levels, but most are moderates.
